front.title: Homenet Simple Source Address Dependent Routing (SADR)

abstract.t: A network is multi-homed to several providers. Each provider assigns provider aggregated addresses to the network and apply BCP38 inbound filtering. This document describes how routers in the network uses source address dependent routing to ensure that traffic is sent out the correct exit given the packets source address.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: In a multi-homed homenet like the one in section 3.2.2.2 of , a network may be numbered with provider aggregated addresses. If each of the network providers employ BCP38 filtering, then traffic must be sent out the correct exit, given the packet's source address. In such a scenario each host has multiple addresses from each of the providers the network is connected to. The host chooses with provider to use based on which source address it selects.

In a network with an arbitrary topology of multiple border routers connected to external providers, and multiple internal routers, a router must not only forward packets based on the destination address but also the source address. This we call source address dependent routing (SADR).

A border router has one or more WAN interfaces connecting it to one or more Service Providers. The interfaces may be "real" or "virtual" in the case of tunneling technology. The border router receives one or more delegated prefixes, each associated with one or more WAN interfaces.

WAN interfaces are used to send ingress traffic from the Internet to the End-User, and egress traffic from the End-User network to the Internet. Ingress traffic may be received on any active interface at any time. Egress traffic follows a set of rules within the router in order to choose the proper WAN interface. This is important not only in order to choose the best path, but also because the networks that the router are connected to typically employ source address verification mechanisms.
SADR is similar to policy based routing, and this memo proposes a simple extension to the destination based longest match algorithm to constrain it to source address.
This document describes a solution to the SADR problem in the context of a home network that is using OSPFv3 prefix assignment as described in .

section.title: Conventions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119 .

list.t: A Source Address Routing Information Base containing an entry per delegated prefix. Each entry points to one or more Destination Address Routing Tables (DRIB).
A Destination Address Routing Information Base used for destination address longest matching lookups. Each entry points to one or more next-hops.

section.title: Source Address Dependent Routing in the Home Network
section.t: In a destination based routing table, an entry in the routing table can be shown as "D -> NH". That is, to get to a destination D, use next-hop NH. For a source constrained routing table we propose the following notation. (Source network, Destination network) -> Next-hop. (S,D) -> NH. A route that is not source constrained can be represented as (D, *) -> NH.

For convenience this document shows the routing table as a single destination based routing table, with source address constrained paths. This does not preclude other implementations, as long as the external behaviour is the same.

A router forwarding a packet does a longest match lookup on the destination address. If this is a (D,*) entry, it forwards the packet out the best next-hop as before (doing equal cost multi path load balancing etc). If the lookup results in a (D, S) entry, the lookup function does a longest match on the source address among the set of (D, S) paths. If there is a match the packet is forwarded out the given next-hop, if not an ICMP destination address unreachable message is returned. A routing entry may have both (D,S) paths and (D,*) paths. The longest match wins.

The following example show the routing table of a network connected to two ISPs, ISP A and ISP B. Both ISPs offer default connectivity and ISP B also offers a more specific route to a walled garden service.

figure.title: Example Routing Table
figure.artwork: (2001:db8::/56, ::/0) -> ISP_A # Default route to ISP A (2001:db9::/56, ::/0) -> ISP_B # Default route to ISP B (*, 2001:db8::/64) -> R1 # Internal network, prefix from A (*, 2001:db8:1::/64) -> R2 # Internal network, prefix from A (*, 2001:db9::/64) -> R1 # Internal network, prefix from B (*, 2001:db9:1::/64) -> R2 # Internal network, prefix from B (*, fd00::/64) -> R3 # Internal network ULA (2001:db9::/56, 2001:420::/32) -> ISP_B # Walled garden route from ISP B

section.t: A packet with the SA,DA of 2001:db8::1, 2001:dead:beef::1 would be forwarded to ISP A, likewise a packet with SA, DA 2001:db9::1, 2001:dead:beef::1 would be forward to ISP B. An packet with SA,DA 2001:db8::1, 2001:db9::1 would be forwarded using normal destination based routing. A packet to the walled garden SA,DA 2001:db9::1, 2001:420::1 would be sent to ISP B. A packet with SA,DA 2001:db8::1,2001:420::1 would be dropped with an ICMP unreachable message being sent back.

section.title: Routing considerations
section.t: Now that we have described the function of the source constrained routing table. How does the table get populated? The generic answer is that the routing protocol used in the network has to be extended to support (D,S) routes.

In the home network it is possible to take advantage of the fact that the source constrained prefix is available as part of the prefix assignment mechanism. An internal router can combine the information learnt from prefix assignment with the External routes being learnt in the routing protocol advertisements.

All routers are running OSPFv3 with the extensions for auto-configuration and prefix assignment. A border router typically advertises a default route and any other external routes that it has learnt (e.g. with RFC4191) into the OSPFv3 domain. These routes are advertised in an AS-External LSA, .

An internal router when receiving a AS-External LSA route will install that in the routing table as normal. When the internal router receives a usable prefix as part of prefix assignment, the router shall add source constrained entries to all the AS-External routes received from the same border router (matching router-ID).
Routes that are not associcated with a border router or is not AS-External do not have source constrained paths.

list.t: Routing protocol must flood all information to all routers in the home network.
Prefix assignment and unicast routing must be done in the same protocol.
A router must be uniquely identified (router-id) so that router advertisements and prefix assignment can be tied together
